sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Renal cell carcinoma, Advanced: 800 mg ORALLY once daily without food; initial dose reduction should be 400 mg, with additional dose decreases or increases in 200-mg increments based on tolerability; MAX dose 800 mg/day
  • Soft tissue sarcoma, Advanced, in patients who have received prior chemotherapy: 800 mg ORALLY once daily without food; increase or decrease dose in 200-mg increments based on tolerability; MAX dose 800 mg/day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: no dosage adjustment necessary
  • hepatic impairment (moderate): 200 mg ORALLY once a day
  • hepatic impairment (severe): use not recommended
  • hepatotoxicity (isolated ALT greater than 8 x ULN): interrupt pazopanib until return to grade 1 or baseline; may reinitiate at no more than 400 mg ORALLY daily; if ALT recurs to greater than 3 x ULN, permanently discontinue
  • hepatotoxicity (ALT greater than 3 x ULN and bilirubin greater than 2 x ULN): permanently discontinue
  • hepatotoxicity (mild indirect hyperbilirubinemia, known Gilbert syndrome, and ALT greater than 3 x ULN): interrupt pazopanib until return to grade 1 or baseline; may reinitiate at no more than 400 mg ORALLY daily; if ALT recurs to greater than 3 x ULN, permanently discontinue
  • wound healing: stop pazopanib at least 7 days prior to surgery and resume after surgery based on adequate wound healing; discontinue in patients with wound dehiscence
  • hypertension: interrupt or reduce dose; discontinue if evidence of hypertension crisis or if severe and persistent despite antihypertensive therapy and dose reduction
  • proteinuria (24-hour urine protein measurement 3 g or greater): discontinue pazopanib
  • use with strong CYP3A4 inducers (eg, rifampin): avoid use and consider alternative medication with no or minimal enzyme induction activity
  • use with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (eg, ketoconazole): reduce pazopanib dose to 400 mg and further reduce dose if adverse effects occur

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Renal cell carcinoma, Advanced
  • Soft tissue sarcoma, Advanced, in patients who have received prior chemotherapy

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
Severe and fatal hepatotoxicity has occurred during clinical trials. Monitor hepatic function in all patients. Interrupt, reduce, or discontinue treatment as recommended.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- Severe and fatal hepatotoxicity has been reported, with transaminase elevations typically occurring within the first 18 weeks of treatment; monitoring recommended; dose reduction, interruption, or discontinuation may be necessary
  • Cardiovascular:
  • -- Arterial thromboembolic events (myocardial infarction or ischemia, cerebrovascular accident, and transient ischemic attack), including fatalities, have been reported
  • -- Avoid use in patients with history of arterial thromboembolic events within the past 6 months
  • -- Cardiac dysfunction, including congestive heart failure and decreased left ventricular ejection fraction, has occurred; monitoring recommended; dose adjustments may be required
  • -- Hypertension, including hypertensive crisis has been reported, typically occurring within the first 18 weeks of treatment; dose reduction or discontinuation may be needed and monitoring is recommended; dose reduction or permanent discontinuation may be required
  • -- QT prolongation and torsades de pointes have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • -- Use caution in patients with a history of QT interval prolongation, preexisting cardiac disease, or concurrent use of antiarrhythmics or other QT-prolonging medications; monitoring recommended
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Hypothyroidism has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Gastrointestinal:
  • -- Gastrointestinal perforation and fistula, including fatal perforations, have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Hemorrhagic events including fatal cases, have been reported
  • -- Thrombotic microangiography (TMA), including thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and hemolytic uremic syndrome has occurred with monotherapy and in clinical trials in combination (unapproved use) with bevacizumab and topotecan; monitoring recommended; permanently discontinue if TMA develops
  • -- Use not recommended in patients with hemoptysis, cerebra hemorrhagel, or clinically significant gastrointestinal hemorrhage in past 6 months
  • -- Venous thromboembolic events (VTE) including fatal pulmonary embolism, have occurred; monitoring recommended
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Dose reductions recommended in patients with moderate hepatic impairment (total bilirubin greater than 1.5 times the ULN to 3 times ULN)
  • -- Use not recommended in patients with severe hepatic impairment (total bilirubin greater than 3 times ULN)
  • -- Hepatotoxicity, manifested as increased in ALT, AST, and bilirubin, have been reported; increased risk in patients older than 65 years; monitoring recommended
  • -- Interrupt treatment and consider discontinuation in patients with Gilbert's syndrome, in conjunction with ALT elevation greater than 3 times the ULN
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Serious infections, including fatalities, have been reported; monitoring recommended and dose interruption or discontinuation may be necessary
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Reversible posterior leukoencephalopathy syndrome, which may be fatal in some cases, has been reported; permanent discontinuation is required
  • Renal:
  • -- Proteinuria, including 1 case of nephrotic syndrome, has been reported; monitoring recommended and dose reduction, interruption, or discontinuation may be necessary
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Pregnancy should be avoided as drug may cause fetal harm
  • Other:
  • -- Discontinue use in patients with wound dehiscence
  • -- Temporarily discontinue drug at least 7 days prior to scheduled surgery due to increased risk of impaired wound healing; resume treatment based on clinical status and adequate wound healing
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Avoid concomitant use with agents that raise gastric pH; if required may consider short-acting antacids separated by 2 hours from pazopanib administration
  • -- Avoid concomitant use with strong CYP3A4 inducers (eg, rifampin)
  • -- Avoid concomitant use with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (eg, ketoconazole, ritonavir, clarithromycin); reduce pazopanib dose if coadministration clinically indicated
  • -- Avoid concomitant use with strong P-glycoprotein or breast cancer resistance protein (BCRP) inhibitors
  • -- Avoid consumption of grapefruit or grapefruit juice
  • -- Concomitant use of drugs with a narrow therapeutic window and metabolized by CYP3A4, CYP2D6, or CYP2C8 is not recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Pazopanib: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension, All grades (renal cell carcinoma, 40%; soft tissue sarcoma, 42%)
  • Dermatologic:Hair color change (renal cell carcinoma, 38%; soft tissue sarcoma, 39%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Decreased albumin (all grades, 34%; grade 3, 1%), Hypomagnesemia (all grades, 26%; grade 3, less than 1%; grade 4, 1%), Hyponatremia (31%), Hypophosphatemia (all grades, 34%; grade 3, 4%), Increased glucose level (renal cell carcinoma, 41%; soft tissue sarcoma, 45%), Weight decreased (renal cell carcinoma, 9%; soft tissue sarcoma, 48%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Decrease in appetite (all grades, 40%; grade 3, 6%), Diarrhea (renal cell carcinoma, 52%; soft tissue sarcoma, 59%), Loss of appetite (all grades, 22%; grade 3, 2%), Nausea (renal cell carcinoma, 26%; soft tissue sarcoma, 56%), Vomiting (renal cell carcinoma, 21%; soft tissue sarcoma, 33%)
  • Hematologic:Leukopenia, All grades (renal cell carcinoma, 37%; soft tissue sarcoma, 44%), Neutropenia, All grades (renal cell carcinoma, 34%; soft tissue sarcoma, 33%), Thrombocytopenia, All grades (renal cell carcinoma, 32%; soft tissue sarcoma, 36%)
  • Hepatic:Alkaline phosphatase raised (32%)
  • Immunologic:Lymphocytopenia, All grades (renal cell carcinoma, 31%; soft tissue sarcoma, 43%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Musculoskeletal pain (all grades, 23%; grade 3, 2%), Myalgia (all grades, 23%; grade 3, 2%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (renal cell carcinoma, 10%; soft tissue sarcoma, 23%)
  • Respiratory:Dyspnea (all grades, 20%; grade 3, 5%; grade 4, less than 1%)
  • Other:Cancer pain (all grades, 29%; grade 3, 8%), Fatigue (renal cell carcinoma, 19%; soft tissue sarcoma, 65%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Congestive heart failure (soft tissue sarcoma, 1%), Hypertension, Grade 3 or 4 (renal cell carcinoma, 4%; soft tissue sarcoma, 7%), Hypertensive crisis, Left ventricular cardiac dysfunction (renal cell carcinoma, 0.6%; soft tissue sarcoma, 8%), Myocardial infarction (renal cell carcinoma, 2%; soft tissue sarcoma, 2%), Prolonged QT interval (renal cell carcinoma, 2%; soft tissue sarcoma, 0.2%), Torsades de pointes (less than 1%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypothyroidism (4% to 7%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Bleeding from anus (2%), Bleeding from mouth (3%), Gastrointestinal fistula, Gastrointestinal perforation, Pancreatitis (less than 1%), Rectal hemorrhage (1%)
  • Hematologic:Hemorrhage (renal cell carcinoma, 13%; soft tissue sarcoma, 22%), Leukopenia, Grade 3 or 4 (soft tissue sarcoma, 1%), Neutropenia, Grade 3 or 4 (renal cell carcinoma, 1% to less than 2%; soft tissue sarcoma, 4%), Thrombocytopenia, Grade 3 or 4 (renal cell carcinoma, less than 1% to less than 2%; soft tissue sarcoma, 4%), Thrombotic microangiopathy, Venous thromboembolism (renal cell carcinoma, 1%; soft tissue sarcoma, 5%)
  • Hepatic:ALT/SGPT level raised (Renal cell carcinoma, 53%; soft tissue sarcoma, 46%), AST/SGOT level raised (Renal cell carcinoma, 53%; soft tissue sarcoma, 51%), Hepatotoxicity (2%), Increased bilirubin level (Renal cell carcinoma, 36%; soft tissue sarcoma, 29%)
  • Immunologic:Infectious disease, Lymphocytopenia, Grade 3 or 4 (renal cell carcinoma, 4% to less than 5%; soft tissue sarcoma, 10%)
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident (renal cell carcinoma, 0.3%; soft tissue sarcoma, 0.4%), Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome, Transient ischemic attack (renal cell carcinoma, 1%)
  • Respiratory:Pneumothorax (soft tissue sarcoma, 3%), Pulmonary embolism, Fatal (0% to 1%)

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Pazopanib is an inhibitor of multiple tyrosine kinases that is indicated for the treatment of advanced renal cell carcinoma. It inhibits vascular endothelial growth factor receptors 1, 2 and 3, platelet-derived growth factor receptors alpha and beta, fibroblast growth factor receptors 1 and 3, cytokine receptor (Kit), interleukin-2 receptor inducible T-cell kinase (Itk), leukocyte-specific protein tyrosine kinase (Lck), and transmembrane glycoprotein receptor tyrosine kinase (c-Fms).

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: whole tablet, 2 to 4 hr; crushed tablet, decreased by about 2 hr compared to whole tablet
  • Bioavailability, Oral: whole tablet, unspecified; crushed tablet, increased bioavailability and rate or absorption
  • Effects of food: increased systemic exposure (2-fold increase in AUC and Cmax)

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: Hepatic: via CYP3A4 (major); CYP1A2 and CYP2C8 (minor)

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
Oral
  • take without food (1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal)
  • do not crush tablets

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• clinical or radiologic evidence of tumor regression indicates efficacy
  • hepatic function; baseline, weeks 3, 5, 7, and 9, month 3 and 4 and periodically after month 4 as clinically indicated
  • hepatic function; weekly in patients with isolated ALT elevations between 3 and 8 times the ULN
  • electrolytes; baseline and periodically during therapy
  • thyroid function tests; during therapy
  • urinalysis for proteinuria; baseline and periodically thereafter
  • ECG; baseline and periodically during therapy
  • blood pressure; during therapy.
  • signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure
  • LVEF; baseline and periodically during therapy in patients at risk for cardiac dysfunction.
  • signs and symptoms of VTE and pulmonary embolus
  • signs and symptoms of thrombotic microangiopathy
  • signs and symptoms of gastrointestinal perforation or fistula
  • signs and symptoms of infection

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
PAZOPANIB
USES: Indicated for the treatment of advanced renal cell carcinoma. PHARMACOLOGY: Inhibitor of multiple tyrosine kinases, including vascular endothelial growth factor receptors 1, 2 and 3, platelet-derived growth factor receptors alpha and beta, fibroblast growth factor receptors 1 and 3, cytokine receptor, interleukin-2 receptor inducible T-cell kinase, leukocyte-specific protein tyrosine kinase, and transmembrane glycoprotein receptor tyrosine kinase. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. MILD TO MODERATE POISONING: Fatigue and hypertension were reported in patients receiving 2,000 mg daily and 1,000 mg daily, respectively. SEVERE POISONING: Severe toxicity following overdose has not been reported. Overdose effects are anticipated to be an extension of adverse effects observed following therapeutic doses, and may include myelosuppression, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, hypertension, and possibly QTc prolongation, bleeding and hepatotoxicity. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: The most common adverse effects following therapeutic administration include: bone marrow suppression (i.e., leukopenia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia), hypertension, hair depigmentation, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and anorexia. RARE: QT prolongation, torsades de pointes, hemorrhagic events (i.e., pulmonary, gastrointestinal, genitourinary, and cerebral hemorrhage), and severe hepatotoxicity, with fatalities, have been rarely reported with pazopanib therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
PAZOPANIB
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Treat severe hypertension with nitroprusside as the preferred agent; nitroglycerin or phentolamine as alternatives. QT prolongation and torsades de pointes have been reported with therapeutic doses and may occur following overdose. Treat torsades de pointes with IV magnesium sulfate and correct electrolyte abnormalities; use overdrive pacing. Hemorrhagic events (pulmonary, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary) have been observed. Myelosuppression has been reported. For severe neutropenia, administer colony stimulating factor (e.g., filgrastim, sargramostim). Transfusions as needed for severe thrombocytopenia, bleeding.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Consider activated charcoal in patients who are awake and able to maintain their airway. HOSPITAL: Consider activated charcoal after a potentially toxic ingestion and if the patient is able to maintain airway or if airway is protected.
  • Antidote: None.
  • Hypertensive episode: Mild/moderate asymptomatic hypertension does not usually require treatment. For severe hypertension, nitroprusside is preferred, with nitroglycerin or phentolamine as alternatives.
  • Torsades de pointes: IV magnesium sulfate, correct electrolyte abnormalities, use overdrive pacing.
  • Myelosuppression: Severe neutropenia: filgrastim 5 mcg/kg/day subcutaneously, or sargramostim 250 mcg/m(2)/day infused over 4 hours. Transfusions as needed for severe thrombocytopenia, bleeding.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs and liver enzymes after significant overdose. Monitor fluid and electrolyte status in patients with significant vomiting and/or diarrhea. Monitor serial CBC with differential and platelet counts. Institute continuous cardiac monitoring and obtain serial ECGs to evaluate for evidence of QT prolongation.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis is unlikely to be effective due to high protein binding (>99%).
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Asymptomatic adults with inadvertent ingestions (or an inadvertent single extra dose) can be monitored at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: All patients with deliberate self-harm ingestions should be evaluated in a healthcare facility and monitored until symptoms resolve. Children with unintentional ingestions should be observed in a healthcare facility. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients demonstrating severe fluid and electrolyte imbalance, cardiovascular instability, or severe hepatotoxicity should be admitted. CONSULT CRITERIA: Call a Poison Center for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
PAZOPANIB
TOXICITY: A toxic dose has not been established. Grade 3 fatigue and grade 3 hypertension were reported in patients receiving 2,000 mg daily and 1,000 mg daily, respectively. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: The recommended dose is 800 mg orally once daily.
